content.raw:
There's one behavioral detail which I'm not sure what the "right" approach would be:

Right now, when a user calls `Node::Unsubscribe(const std::string& _topic)`, it will unsubscribe both ordinary subscribers to `_topic` and raw subscribers to `_topic`. Should I instead create a separate function `Node::RawUnsubscribe` which deals with raw subscriptions separately?

As it currently stands on the `default` branch, `Node::Unsubscribe(_topic)` is already somewhat blunt, since it will unsubscribe all subscriptions to `_topic` regardless of the message type expected by the subscriber. Making it so that `Node::Unsubscribe` also removes raw subscriptions seems consistent with that behavior, so I think the current behavior on this branch makes sense. If anyone thinks that unsubscribing the raw subscribers should be handled separately, please let me know, and I can change this behavior.
content.html:
There's one behavioral detail which I'm not sure what the "right" approach would be:

Right now, when a user calls Node::Unsubscribe(const std::string& _topic), it will unsubscribe both ordinary subscribers to _topic and raw subscribers to _topic. Should I instead create a separate function Node::RawUnsubscribe which deals with raw subscriptions separately?

As it currently stands on the default branch, Node::Unsubscribe(_topic) is already somewhat blunt, since it will unsubscribe all subscriptions to _topic regardless of the message type expected by the subscriber. Making it so that Node::Unsubscribe also removes raw subscriptions seems consistent with that behavior, so I think the current behavior on this branch makes sense. If anyone thinks that unsubscribing the raw subscribers should be handled separately, please let me know, and I can change this behavior.

content.raw:
Most users will not directly call `Node::Unsubscribe`. The typical use-case is to let the node fall out of scope, and let unsubscribe happen automatically.

That being said, I'm in favor of `Unsubscribe` unsubscribing all subscribers from a topic, both raw and regular.
content.html:
Most users will not directly call Node::Unsubscribe. The typical use-case is to let the node fall out of scope, and let unsubscribe happen automatically.

That being said, I'm in favor of Unsubscribe unsubscribing all subscribers from a topic, both raw and regular.

Yep, that's in the works right now.

One thing I'm not sure about is whether we want to write the same breadth of tests for the raw publish/subscribe as we currently have for the normal publish/subscribe. Granted, that could be accomplished easily enough by a lot of copy/pasting, but that might be a lot of unnecessary noise.
content.html:
Yep, that's in the works right now.

One thing I'm not sure about is whether we want to write the same breadth of tests for the raw publish/subscribe as we currently have for the normal publish/subscribe. Granted, that could be accomplished easily enough by a lot of copy/pasting, but that might be a lot of unnecessary noise.

content.raw: (Especially if we want full breadth on all combinations of raw publish -> raw subscribe, normal publish -> raw subscribe, raw publish -> normal subscribe)
content.html: (Especially if we want full breadth on all combinations of raw publish -> raw subscribe, normal publish -> raw subscribe, raw publish -> normal subscribe)

content.raw: Is duplicating the tests needed to cover all of the code?
content.html: Is duplicating the tests needed to cover all of the code?

content.raw:
To cover all of the code through all possible paths, kind of.

There are certain types of tests that we really shouldn't need to duplicate. For example, there are numerous different overloads of the `Node::Subscribe` function which allow users to subscribe to a topic with a variety of callback function signatures. Those different versions of `Node::Subscribe` ultimately funnel into one specific overload of the function. So if we want to test raw publish -> normal subscribe, it should be sufficient to test it against that baseline overload of `Node::Subscribe` and disregard the other overloads.

But there are lots of other combinations of things being tested, like [single|multiple] [publishers|subscribers], or different scenarios like subscribing with the wrong message type. For those cases, it's much less clear to me whether we should be duplicating the tests.
content.html:
To cover all of the code through all possible paths, kind of.

There are certain types of tests that we really shouldn't need to duplicate. For example, there are numerous different overloads of the Node::Subscribe function which allow users to subscribe to a topic with a variety of callback function signatures. Those different versions of Node::Subscribe ultimately funnel into one specific overload of the function. So if we want to test raw publish -> normal subscribe, it should be sufficient to test it against that baseline overload of Node::Subscribe and disregard the other overloads.

But there are lots of other combinations of things being tested, like [single|multiple] [publishers|subscribers], or different scenarios like subscribing with the wrong message type. For those cases, it's much less clear to me whether we should be duplicating the tests.

content.raw: Agreed that there's a lot of duplication in the tests, we don't have enough infrastructure to do it in a better way yet. I would try to cover at least the basic functionality in the interprocess case. Of course, ideas to improve it are more than welcome.
content.html: Agreed that there's a lot of duplication in the tests, we don't have enough infrastructure to do it in a better way yet. I would try to cover at least the basic functionality in the interprocess case. Of course, ideas to improve it are more than welcome.

content.raw: I considered trying something with parameterized test fixtures, but I think it would be a lot more legwork than it's worth right now. Maybe if we have time to revisit the test suite in the future, we can work out something more elegant and comprehensive. For now, I'll just resort to copy/paste/tweaking to create the new tests.
content.html: I considered trying something with parameterized test fixtures, but I think it would be a lot more legwork than it's worth right now. Maybe if we have time to revisit the test suite in the future, we can work out something more elegant and comprehensive. For now, I'll just resort to copy/paste/tweaking to create the new tests.

content.raw: If you refer to a function, such as `CheckHandlerInfo`, then give the full signature: `HandlerInfo CheckHandlerInfo(const std::string &_topic) const`. This will allow doxygen to create a link to that function.
content.html: If you refer to a function, such as CheckHandlerInfo, then give the full signature: HandlerInfo CheckHandlerInfo(const std::string &_topic) const. This will allow doxygen to create a link to that function.

content.raw:
From the [doxygen documentation](https://www.stack.nl/~dimitri/doxygen/manual/autolink.html) it looks like the return value and parameter names are never needed, but the trailing `const` can sometimes be needed since it's part of the function signature and may be necessary for disambiguation. In the absence of a non-const version of the function, the trailing const can be omitted. There's also:

> For non overloaded members the argument list may be omitted.

I don't imagine this function will ever be overloaded since it has a very specific purpose, but I'll add in all of the suggested changes anyway, because it probably won't hurt anything.
content.html:
From the doxygen documentation it looks like the return value and parameter names are never needed, but the trailing const can sometimes be needed since it's part of the function signature and may be necessary for disambiguation. In the absence of a non-const version of the function, the trailing const can be omitted. There's also:

For non overloaded members the argument list may be omitted.

I don't imagine this function will ever be overloaded since it has a very specific purpose, but I'll add in all of the suggested changes anyway, because it probably won't hurt anything.

content.raw:
I can think of two solutions.

1. If the functions `Partition()` and `NameSpace()` are just meant to forward the `Partition()` and `NameSpace()` functions from `Options()`, then we just define them as a wrapped up call to `this->Options()->Partition()` and `this->Options()->NameSpace()`.

2. Alternatively, we could just remove the function declarations of `Partition()` and `NameSpace()` and allow users to access those fields by calling `Options()->Partition()` and `Options()->NameSpace()`. This shouldn't harm any users, since anyone who has attempted to call `NameSpace()` or `Partition()` up until now would have gotten a linking error at compile time.
content.html:
I can think of two solutions.

  1. If the functions Partition() and NameSpace() are just meant to forward the Partition() and NameSpace() functions from Options(), then we just define them as a wrapped up call to this->Options()->Partition() and this->Options()->NameSpace().

  2. Alternatively, we could just remove the function declarations of Partition() and NameSpace() and allow users to access those fields by calling Options()->Partition() and Options()->NameSpace(). This shouldn't harm any users, since anyone who has attempted to call NameSpace() or Partition() up until now would have gotten a linking error at compile time.

content.raw:
Sorry for not catching this comment.

The message type won't be known if it advertised itself as a generic Protobuf message type. We use the generic message type as a catch-all for advertising and subscribing.
content.html:
Sorry for not catching this comment.

The message type won't be known if it advertised itself as a generic Protobuf message type. We use the generic message type as a catch-all for advertising and subscribing.

content.raw: Also note that if `_msgType` doesn't match the message type that it advertised itself as, the `PublishRaw` function will return false and not publish the message (unless it was originally advertised as a generic publisher, in which case it returns true and allows the message through). This gives us an (albeit small) extra layer of confidence that the person requesting the publication knows what they're doing.
content.html: Also note that if _msgType doesn't match the message type that it advertised itself as, the PublishRaw function will return false and not publish the message (unless it was originally advertised as a generic publisher, in which case it returns true and allows the message through). This gives us an (albeit small) extra layer of confidence that the person requesting the publication knows what they're doing.

content.html: You mean to use google::protobuf::Message in Advertise(), and then, use the specific type in RawPublish() (ignition::msgs::StringMsg for example)?

content.raw:
Conflicts should be resolved 7b4933d

One possible concern is that local raw subscribers are still single-threaded, even though the local ordinary subscribers are using the `WorkerPool` to multithread.

We could make the raw subscriptions multi-threaded, we would just need to make a copy of the serialized data `msgBuffer` into a `std::shared_ptr` to ensure that the data is safe for multithreading.
content.html:
Conflicts should be resolved 7b4933d

One possible concern is that local raw subscribers are still single-threaded, even though the local ordinary subscribers are using the WorkerPool to multithread.

We could make the raw subscriptions multi-threaded, we would just need to make a copy of the serialized data msgBuffer into a std::shared_ptr to ensure that the data is safe for multithreading.

content.raw: Raw subscribers now use the `WorkerPool` as of 0f6fc56
content.html: Raw subscribers now use the WorkerPool as of 0f6fc56
